posts.cooked:
TL;DR: Choose official coding guideline to shut down wasteful pointless arguments.

While Urho3D have coding style guidelines (stuff like naming & indentation), it doesn‚Äôt have coding guidelines.

Considering arguments block PRs, and since @cadaver left, I think it‚Äôs important to have agreed upon official guidelines so we can point bikeshedders to them to shut down the argument, so they won‚Äôt waste time and block progress.

Since it‚Äôs pointless to try to argue with ‚ÄúPoisonous People‚Äù[1], because:

  • They don‚Äôt listen
  • They just want to keep arguing forever

I‚Äôm in favor of using C++ Core Guidelines, and here are the reasons:

  • It‚Äôs written and reviewed by a lot of people, including experts like C++ committee members.
  • It addresses a lot of topics - less opportunities for arguments.
  • At least with Visual Studio, there‚Äôs static analysis checker for the Core Guidelines.
  • It‚Äôs designed for modern C++

Note that the goal of using a coding guideline (at least for me) is not to fanatically follow it, but to shut down wasteful arguments by already having official rules in place.

1 - Poisonous People:

Please vote:

  • Let‚Äôs use C++ Core Guidelines
  • Let‚Äôs use some other guideline (please explain which and why)
  • I‚Äôm against using guidelines

posts.cooked:
My answer is 2. Detailed opinion is below.

C++ Core Guidelines pros:

  • Reasonable guideline designed by many clever people;
  • Already written;

Cons:

  • Hard to check code conformity. All contributors literally have to read and re-read 100-pages paper.
  • The guideline interferes with Urho legacy code;

The last item is most important here.

If there is a conflict between contribution and legacy, it must be resolved before merge. This rule is obvious for code contributions.

I don‚Äôt think that code standard contribution is too different from code. If you introduce code standard changes that interfere with legacy code, you should resolve the conflict.

My recent actions is a kind of example.

  1. I committed three strict rules into code standard (override is required, typedef is forbidden, 0 and NULL pointer constants are forbidden)
  2. There become a conflict;
  3. I resolved the conflict. Urho master branch is fully conformant with newly committed coding conventions;

Some new C++11 features doesn‚Äôt replace old counterparts. {}-ctor cannot completely replace ()-ctor, auto cannot completely replace explicit type, inplace member initalization cannot completely replace initializer lists, range-based for cannot completely replace index-based for and so on.

I also committed some weak rules related to these features. These rules are not requirements but suggestions. Such rules doesn‚Äôt interfere with legacy code due to their weak nature.

C++ Core Guidelines are in the conflict with Urho code, so they couldn‚Äôt be commited until the conflicts are resolved either on the guidelines or on the code side.

If the project‚Äôs code doesn‚Äôt meet the project‚Äôs codestyle, it is equal to the absence of the codestyle.
So, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs use C++ Core Guidelines‚Äù is equal to ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs drop codestyle requirements‚Äù.
I couldn‚Äôt vote for such item, with all due respect to C++ Core Guidelines itself (no sarcasm)

Wow, I almost forget about an answer. We should use guidelines that are not in the conflict with Urho legacy.

Eugene:

Hard to check code conformity. All contributors literally have to read and re-read 100-pages paper.

You literally have static analysis tool that automatically do it (didn‚Äôt you read what I wrote?). Also you don‚Äôt have to read it all, it‚Äôs very organized and broken into categories and short points on each topic.

Eugene:

The guideline interferes with Urho legacy code;

Doesn‚Äôt matter. There‚Äôs absolutely 0 need to go back and upgrade all existing code.
Just apply it to new code.
Your ‚Äúconflict‚Äù is a non-issue.

There‚Äôs no need to fanatically follow a guideline.

Here is the list of items that I don‚Äôt want to be in the Urho. This is quite small subset of C++ Core Guidelines, isn‚Äôt it?

Block

ES.107: Don‚Äôt use unsigned for subscripts
C.133: Avoid protected data

Block or perform API-breaking refactoring:

Enum.3: Prefer class enums over ‚Äúplain‚Äù enums
Enum.5: Don‚Äôt use ALL_CAPS for enumerators

Block or perform refactoring

C.128: Virtual functions should specify exactly one of virtual, override, or final

Block or use EASTL

ES.1: Prefer the standard library to other libraries and to "handcrafted code"
ES.27: Use std::array or stack_array for arrays on the stack

I agree with you against:
ES.107: Don‚Äôt use unsigned for subscripts -
use what the container‚Äôs size type. The claim about performance needs to be proved.

C.133: Avoid protected data

I disagree with you against (not saying we should use them, just that they‚Äôre not wrong):
Enum.3: Prefer class enums over ‚Äúplain‚Äù enums -
prefer only. They‚Äôre hard to use for indexing anyway so they‚Äôre aren‚Äôt the default choice. I‚Äôm not sure if they work with AngelScript too.

Enum.5: Don‚Äôt use ALL_CAPS for enumerators -
just easier to read non-all caps.

C.128: Virtual functions should specify exactly one of virtual, override, or final -
override is implicitly virtual. mixing final with the others doesnt make sense

ES.1: Prefer the standard library to other libraries and to ‚Äúhandcrafted code‚Äù -
standard STL is actually faster than Urho‚Äôs in some cases. Need to benchmark EASTL against STL/Urho. Using STL is easier. An argument against std STL is that different compilers got different implementations which can lead to inconsistency.

ES.27: Use std::array or stack_array for arrays on the stack -
std::array is more convenient than C array.

There‚Äôs no need to 100% follow everything in it.
